oai_dc:dc.dc:title: RUN-UP AT RUBBLE MOUND BREAKWATERS WITH SUBMERGED BERM: AN EXPERIMENTAL STUDY
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Celli, Daniele
Castellino, Myrta
Pasquali, Davide
Nucci, Carmine Di
Girolamo, Paolo De
Risio, Marcello Di
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the recent years, the effects of climate change are becoming increasingly evident (e.g., Naughten et al., 2023; PÃ¶rtner et al., 2022). Sea level rise, change in the intensity of storm surge, and wave heights are typical consequences of climate change in the coastal environment (e.g., Toimil et al., 2020). Therefore, coastal structures deployed to protect coastlines and harbors from wave action, may become ineffective due to the potential increase of wave loads, run-up, and overtopping phenomena (e.g., Galiatsatou et al., 2018). Indeed, several adaptation measures for existing coastal structures have been proposed (e.g., Burcharth et al., 2014). Past research studies illustrated how the deployment of a berm in the seaward side of conventional rubble mound breakwaters can significantly improve the performance of the structure. (e.g. Van Gent, 2013; Celli et al., 2018; Celli et al., 2021). Basically, the presence of a berm enhances the wave energy dissipation at the toe of the armor layer. Besides the stability of the structure, this could be effective in the reduction of wave run-up, and overtopping phenomena, potentially. To investigate the role of the submerged berm on the wave run-up phenomenon, a series of 2D experimental tests is being carried out at the Environmental and Maritime Hydraulic Laboratory (LIam) of the University of L'Aquila.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; structures.105
